abstracts.cdata!:
Five themes are the focus for
            environmental analysis of the Forest Management and
            Conservation Project: 1) forest policy, legal and regulatory
            framework; 2) commercial forestry; 3) community-based
            forestry; 4) conservation and biodiversity protection; and
            5) institutional structure and capacity.  The objectives of
            the project are to: 1) institute a new resource management
            system for balanced and sustainable use, conservation and
            protection; 2) implement a clear forest policy that fosters
            sustainable use and guardianship; 3) underpin policy with
            requisite legal assurance on critical issues of forest
            access and use; 4) implement policy-based incentives for all
            stakeholders - commercial loggers, villagers, and government
            - to adopt sustainable practices; and 5) unify government
            forestry institutions.  Beyond policy, legal/regulatory and
            institutional reform, the project creates new capacity among
            government institutions and commercial and community
            forest-users to plan, manage and use forests sustainably.
            It also underwrites three national programs on forest
            inventory and zoning; economic use and environmental
            conservation; and a system of protected areas for
            biodiversity conservation.
